case_vignette: A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right-sided facial weakness that he noticed after waking up. One month ago, he also experienced right-sided neck pain and headache that began after returning from a hunting trip to New Hampshire the week before. He took ibuprofen to relieve symptoms, which subsided a week later. He has a 5-year history of hypertension controlled with drug therapy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years and he drinks two beers daily. His vital signs are within the normal range. Physical examination shows right-sided drooping of the upper and lower half of the face. The patient has difficulties smiling and he is unable to close his right eye. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have right-sided facial weakness that I noticed when I woke up.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I just noticed the facial weakness when I woke up today.
Do you have any other symptoms, such as difficulty with speaking or swallowing?
No, I don't have any trouble speaking or swallowing.
Have you noticed any changes in your taste, or have you experienced tearing or drooling on the affected side?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in taste, tearing, or drooling.
Are you able to close your eyelid and raise your eyebrow on the affected side?
I'm unable to close my right eye.
Do you have any ear pain or have you had a recent illness such as a cold or flu?
No, I haven't had any ear pain or a cold or flu recently.
Have you experienced any recent trauma or injury to your head or face?
No, I haven't had any recent trauma or injury to my head or face.
Do you have any other medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
I have high blood pressure and I'm taking medication for it.
Do you have a family history of neurological disorders?
I don't know of any neurological disorders in my family.
Have you experienced any numbness or tingling on the affected side of your face or in any other parts of your body?
No, I haven't felt any numbness or tingling on my face or elsewhere.
**Final Diagnosis:** Bell's palsy.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the clinic with right-sided facial weakness that was noticed upon waking up. The patient reports no trouble speaking or swallowing and denies changes in taste, tearing, or drooling. The patient is unable to close their right eye and denies any recent ear pain, cold, flu, trauma, or injury to the head or face. The patient has high blood pressure and is currently taking medication for it. There is no known family history of neurological disorders and the patient denies experiencing numbness or tingling on the face or elsewhere.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is to conduct imaging studies such as MRI or CT scan of the brain to rule out stroke or other central nervous system pathologies and possibly a lumbar puncture if Lyme neuroborreliosis is suspected given his history of a hunting trip in New Hampshire.
trial_0.summarized_frq: Contralateral Upper Motor Neuron lesion (central facial palsy)

trial_1.summarized_conversation: A patient comes in with weakness on the right side of their face that was noticed upon waking up. The only past complaint is right-sided neck pain and a headache about a month ago after a hunting trip. The patient is on medication for high blood pressure, with no known allergies or chronic conditions. There is no known family history of any such medical issues.
trial_1.vignette_frq: The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is to obtain a neuroimaging study, specifically a brain MRI or CT scan, to evaluate for possible stroke or other neurological conditions given the acute onset of unilateral facial weakness.

trial_3.summarized_conversation: A patient is concerned about the weakness on the right side of their face, which they noticed upon waking up in the morning. The patient is having difficulty smiling and cannot close their right eye. They deny having a recent cold or flu. The patient reports drooping on the right side of the face, but no changes in taste, hearing, or sensitivity to sounds. They also deny any pain behind the ear or on the face. The patient confirms that this is a new condition and denies weakness in their arms or legs, as well as difficulty speaking or swallowing. trial_3.vignette_frq: The most appropriate next step in diagnosis is to perform neuroimaging, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), of the brain to rule out stroke and other potential central causes of facial paralysis. Additionally, serologic testing for Lyme disease should be considered due to the patient's history of neck pain and headache following a hunting trip in an area endemic for Lyme disease.
